data.title: Issue No 16 | December - ErpecNews
data.text: an international retail petroleum news digest Contents News from around Europe, The Middle East, America and the rest of the world Page 1 – 6 Supplier News Page 9 Nupigeco Page 16 – 17 www.erpecnews.com OPW – Total Vapour Solution Page 18 Nacs and PEI 2009 review Page 20 Diary dates Page 21 A–Z suppliers listing Page 22 – 23 Issue No 16 | December / January 2009 / 2010 erpecnews international edition Tokheim and Dresser Wayne acquire rohé companies in Central and Eastern Europe Following the collapse of Rohé, the Austrian based service organisation, providing maintenance, construction, installation and forecourt car wash equipment services across Europe, Tokheim announced last month the acquisition of the Romanian, Serbian, Bulgarian, Lithuanian and Latvian subsidiaries of the Rohé Group. A few days later Dresser Wayne confirmed the acquisition of the Rohé subsidiaries in Poland, Hungary, and Czech Republic. Dresser Wayne also intends to complete the acquisition of the shares owned by A. Rohé Holding in Rohé Slovakia and Bach-Rohé in Switzerland over the coming weeks. It’s President EMEA said “Rohé has been a very strong service provider to fuel forecourts across the region and Dresser Wayne are committed to maintaining the highest levels of customer service as we integrate the Rohé operations into our existing European business,” Commenting on the Tokheim acquisition Baudouin de la Tour, COO of Tokheim Group S.A.S said, “We believe that this acquisition further enhances Tokheim’s global service network and offers opportunities that, with the commitment of stable existing local management teams with excellent track records, will benefit these new businesses and their customers”. It must be considered a sad day for Rohé which had grown over the last 20 years on the back of the major multi-national oil companies stretching out to the furthest parts of Eastern Europe, to embrace the emerging markets of the former Eastern block. In the end it seems that it may have paid the price of being in too many countries at the wrong time, however their ground breaking input into the development of some Eastern markets should not be forgotten. OMV and Doðan Holding will continue existing partnership in Petrol Ofisi OMV and Turkish company Doðan Holding have terminated negotiations regarding OMV’s potential acquisition of Doðan Holding’s shares in Petrol Ofisi. Both partners had stated from the beginning that a continuation of the existing partnership may be a possible outcome of the negotiations and both companies have now agreed to continue their partnership. Petrol Ofisi is Turkey’s leading refined oil products marketing company, active both in the retail and commercial business. OMV entered the Turkish market in 2006 by acquiring 34 percent of Petrol Ofisi and has since increased its stake to 41.58 percent. Doðan Holding, owns 54.17 percent. TOTAl choose TOrA 164 Getty stations in US sold to lUKOIl New petrol stations in bosnia Herzegovina lATEST NEWS, EVENTS, JObS ONlINE – WWW.PETrOlPlAZA.COM TOTAL Oil in Turkey has appointed TORA Petrol in its tank automation system tender across 460 stations. A spokesman for TORA petrol says “TORA will perform the necessary project management and infrastructure work for TOTAL such as surveys, civil works, tank drilling, cabling and supply equipment for tank automation system installation. The project will utilise Gilbarco Veeder-Root’s latest TLS-2 consoles and Mag 1.” Getty Petroleum Marketing in the US has sold all assets unrelated to the 890 properties leased from Getty Realty. The transaction includes the sale of 164 branded service station properties to LUkOIL North America for US $ 195.5 million. This transaction with LUkOIL also included contracts to supply approximately 339 other stations and other assets, including its home heating oil and propane gas unit, the company stated. These assets are unrelated to the properties leased from Getty Realty. Vadim Gluzman, CEO of LUkOIL, said: “LUkOIL North America is expected to be the vehicle through which LUkOIL will concentrate its future growth in the United States.” Neftegazincor – the biggest Russian investor in Bosnia Herzegovina – opened another two petrol stations in Eastern Sarajevo last month within its Nestro chain, formerly Petrol.
